awd_titl_txt: RESEARCH-PGR: Deciphering the molecular basis of elite red alder lines and their Frankia alni symbionts
awd_abstract_narration:
Red alder is a hardwood tree of economic importance in the Pacific Northwest, exceeding the annual value of the dominant softwood species Douglas-fir.  Red alder is used for quality cabinetry, utensils and handles, and as a biomass/biofuels crop. It grows in inhospitable environments and on unproductive land, meaning that it does not compete with food production. Demand for saplings suitable for planting currently greatly exceeds supply. With better understanding of its genetics, scientists would be able to breed trees that grow faster and in more inhospitable environments.  This would expand the area available for growing, and increase the annual yield for timber and biomass fuel.  Additionally, red alder does not require nitrogen fertilizers. It achieves this by harnessing Frankia, a microbe, to provide the nitrogen for it. The relationship between the tree and the microbe requires scientific study.  Some Frankia strains are better than others, and some combinations of tree and microbial strains are well suited to certain environments. This project seeks to understand how the red alder genetics, soil type, Frankia strain, and other bacteria in the soil interact to promote tree growth. The result will be the ability to develop new tree strains suited to certain environments, to expand planting to meet growing demand. The project includes training opportunities for students (high school through graduate level) and supports a high school summer innovation academy that targets underserved students. It promotes access to research by native and Hispanic underrepresented groups.

Red alder (Alnus rubra Bong.), has significant economic importance, yet is an orphan in terms of scientific understanding of its genetic variability and its relationship with its nitrogen-fixing symbiont Frankia alni. This project will create an omics-based resource upon which to base a breeding and improvement program, aimed at improving tolerance to abiotic stresses and growth in marginal land area. Objectives are to create the following: (1) a de novo genome reference assembly of an elite high-performing red alder clone, using PacBio sequencing and BioNano physical mapping, (2) reference genome sequences and epigenomic signatures of the five Frankia strains that result in the best tree performance and symbiosis, using PacBio sequencing with epigenetic modifications determined using the SMRTanalysis suite,(3) a dense set of molecular markers to enable accelerated predictive breeding and improvement, through genotyping of 350 tree lines using the TASSEL-GBS pipeline, and (4) measurements of interactions among tree genotype, rhizosphere microbiome, root transcriptome, symbiont (and other endophyte) transcriptomes, and their impacts on juvenile tree growth on good and marginal soils, through 16s rRNA surveys of rhizosphere microbial communities. The project includes a summer science outreach program for underserved high school students.

por.por_cntn:
From 2017-2022 we undertook research on the red alder tree and its nitrogen-fixing symbiotic microbes. The studies began with decoding the DNA sequence of the organism’s chromosomes, in which we identified the plant’s complement of genes, and compared the structure of its genome with some of its close relatives, including silver birch, walnut, and oak. We identified a large set of DNA variants, which are positions in the genome that differ among different individual plants. Such differences often accompany important differences in plant lifestyle, such as tolerance to drought, resistance to pathogens, and growth rate. These variants will be highly useful in genetic studies and in breeding and selection programs that aim to develop tree strains with improved characteristics. We also collected and sequenced DNA from several hundred red alder trees sampled from all over its natural geographic range. These trees embody a vital biodiversity resource, containing plants that are adapted to a wide range of climatic and geographical conditions. As such, their DNA is expected to yield insights crucial to the survival of the species in the face of a heating planet, and will help us preserve valuable forest ecosystems in the Pacific Northwest. We also carried out the first detailed study of the microbes that live inside red alder roots. These bacteria cooperate with the plant in order to enrich it, and in turn the soil, with nitrogen, an essential nutrient. These discoveries will help us better understand how many bacterial species communicate and interact with the roots so as to promote plant growth. As well as studying the genes of red alder, we also examined the many molecules that endow it with medicinal, plant defense, and color properties. This information will help account for its long historical use – including for better understanding its use as timber in aquatic environments, its ethnobotanical value, and for its use in wood/fiber products and musical instruments.

Our research included several training opportunities for students in middle school through graduate level, and supported a high school summer innovation academy that targeted low-income students. This served 160 incoming 9th graders and aimed to close the “summer skills gap”, wherein low-income students lose more academic ground during the vacation compared to their higher income counterparts. The camps attracted a demographic consistent with 65% free-or-reduced lunch, with high percentages of girls and other underrepresented groups. The camps took place at Santa Fe High School and were free of charge to Santa Fe public school students. During their two week long summer camp experience, students engaged in hands-on learning with content experts, participated in labs and experiments, built working models, saw their creations in action, and took interesting field trips. We also provided a rich training environment for high-school and college students, who visited NCGR for 2-3 weeks for an immersive project-based learning experience in DNA sequencing and computational biology. A total of 12 students learned how to purify DNA samples, how to run a cutting edge DNA sequencing instrument, data handling and manipulation skills, and advanced research topics directly relevant to the goals of our research. Education and outreach accomplishments at Washington State University (WSU) included laboratory training of three undergraduate and two high school students: All have completed B.Sc. degrees in science disciplines, with one pursuing a MD-PhD degree.  Additionally, one graduate student completed her PhD degree in Spring, 2023.
